Award.AwardTitle: REVSYS: A revision of New World Ampullariidae: an emerging model system in evolutionary biology and systematics training
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to assess the severity of the biodiversity crisis hinges on addressing the taxonomic impediment -- the serious lack of experts able to identify and classify organisms. This impediment is felt most seriously in the largest groups of animals on earth, the invertebrates, and in particular the mollusks. The primary goal of the project is to assess the diversity and identities of freshwater snails in the family Ampullariidae (apple snails). More than 250 species have been described in this major group of snails, but how many of these are real species, as well as their true identities, is unknown. Knowledge of their diversity and distributions is thus extremely confused and studies of their ecology, behavior, pest status and control are confounded. The project will resolve this confusion by studying the snails' shells, internal anatomy, DNA sequences and behavior.

These snails are important components of many ecosystems. One species of apple snail native to the United States is the key food item of the endangered Everglades kite, but introduced invasive apple snails are potentially serious pests in both natural and wetland agricultural (e.g., rice) ecosystems, as well as being potential vectors of parasites that cause disease in humans and animals. Introduced widely in south-east Asia, they have also become the number one pest of rice. Understanding the identities, relationships and origins of these invasive species is thus of great importance. However, the lack of taxonomic expertise in such groups of snails is a serious problem globally, and so a major focus of the project is training of young scientists both in the United States and in South America in order to build this needed expertise, while also providing tools to assist others such as agricultural and customs inspection officials to correctly identify these species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Apple snails, known scientifically as species in the family Ampullariidae, occur throughout most of the humid tropics and subtropics in generally slow-flowing bodies of water – creeks, ponds, lakes, drainage ditches and so on. There are almost 200 species. They are called ‘apple snails’ because they generally have large round shells. Some species have been introduced outside their native ranges and become invasive. Most notably, species from South America have been introduced to south-east and eastern Asia, where they have become the number one pest of paddy rice. They also carry parasites that cause human diseases.

 

In addition to the role of apple snails as invasive species, they are often keystone species in their natural ranges, that is, species that are crucial to the correct functioning of ecosystems. Furthermore, they offer many opportunities for addressing profound questions of basic biology, from the mechanisms underlying the evolutionary transition from aquatic to terrestrial lifestyles to the role of egg proteins as sunblock to protect developing embryos.

 

Prior to this project, the identities of the pest species were not well understood, yet this is important information necessary in their management. More generally, the systematics (the diversity and delineation of distinct species and the relationships among them) were extremely confused, such that even specialists had great difficulty distinguishing species. Thus any scientific study of apple snails, including their role as pests and disease vectors, was beset with the difficulty that researchers could not be sure which species they were working on, or even if it was more than one species. Therefore, instructive comparison of the results of different studies was often impossible.

 

The project set out to address this problem and disentangle the confusion by combining traditional approaches distinguishing species based on shell features and the internal anatomy of the snails with modern DNA sequencing approaches. The main focus was on the species of South America, as this was where the invasive species originated. Collaboration with researchers in Brazil especially was crucial.

 

The primary goal was to ascertain the number, identities and distributions of the South America species. Comparison with specimens from the invaded regions would then permit correct identification of the invasive species. Extensive field work throughout Brazil, as well as in Uruguay, combined with obtaining specimens from biologists in other countries, resulted in excellent coverage of South American diversity.

 

The project resolved much of the confusion surrounding the identities of the South American species and allowed the main invasive species in Asia to be determined as Pomacea canaliculata and Pomacea maculata. The same two species have been introduced to the continental United States, and Pomacea canaliculata to Hawaii, and have become agricultural and environmental pests. The shell of Pomacea maculata can grow to almost 7 inches, that of Pomacea canaliculata is generally somewhat smaller. Overall, the project identified well over 50 South American species. Publications describing this diversity in detail are either already published, accepted by or submitted to peer-reviewed journals for publication, or are currently in preparation.

 

An additional goal of the project was to set the stage for future research on the systematics of Old World apple snails.
